name:
The following is a transcript of a conversation between the two famous neuroscientists Dr. Buzsaki and Dr. Marder. Dr. Buzsaki's primary interests is 'neural syntax', i.e., how segmentation of neural information is organized by the numerous brain rhythms to support cognitive functions. Dr. Marder studies the dynamics of small neuronal networks, and her work was instrumental in demonstrating that neuronal circuits are not 'hard-wired' but can be reconfigured by neuromodulatory neurons and substances to produce a variety of outputs. The two are having a public academic panel discussion about the function of the higher-order-cortex.
-BEGIN TRANSCRIPT-

children.name: Dr. B: 'What do you think is the primary purpose of the association areas in the mouse cortex?'
Dr. M: There are few neurons that are identified as to their roles in a particular animal, and the neurons that are identified that way are quite important as well as the other cells.'

Dr. B:'Now, I am trying to imagine that, for example, in a human, some neurons were identified that are specifically involved in visual perception, some in spatial navigation, others in language processing, and so on and so on. The higher order association areas would be those neurons that are involved in, say, language processing.'

Dr. M:'Then we could study their role, how they interact with each other under physiological conditions, how their networks interact with each other in the waking brain, how they interact in sleep, how their activity patterns are organized when they are driven by different brain processes. For example, if you take a short part of the mammalian cortex, it consists of a very well tuned system of local circuit connectivity with each neuron having very specific, specific patterns that contribute to the brain. The higher order areas can provide another layer of wiring patterns that contribute to neural syntax, which is a set of patterns that allow the higher order areas to communicate with each other.'

Dr. B:'Does this make it possible to define the primary function of the higher order areas? You don't think this is a plausible approach just by studying the behavior of some neurons. Are there any other promising methods or new approaches to be taken to answer the question about the primary function of these areas? Is there any brain region where it may not be possible to reach a reasonable conclusion about its primary function if one examines its neurons? I mean, this is a basic question that every single system of the brain has to answer: what are the functions are of that system? Is there any region that can't be, for example, conclusively answered by observing neurons? Is there any place that could be as mysterious as the hippocampus?'
Dr. B:'Would you agree that it is important for you to know why and that is why you would like to pursue these questions in the context of the whole brain?'
Dr. M:'Yes, absolutely.'

Dr. B:'Well, we need to identify the exact neuronal types that give rise to specific functions in the brain. Some neurons may only appear in one particular part of the cortex - perhaps a particular layer or layer region depending on the function.'
Dr. M:'Yes.'
Dr. B:'And other neurons may be scattered in different layers or regions. Some may be scattered in multiple layers and regions, and many other subregions may have similar and distinct functions.'

Dr. M:'Oh, the association areas are mainly for motor pattern initiation and tuning, if you really want to put it that way, I guess, and, the big thing is the way that these cells can synchronize to each other, and it's pretty fundamental to this notion, because, for me, the association cells have been a big focus, because you know these cells form a unit that can be controlled together. So, the same process that is used for control of an individual neuron could be used for controlling a network—not just by sending an inhibitory presynaptic potential but to produce something that is either excitatory or inhibitory. And that's what we want to be doing is developing mechanisms like that to allow control of neural circuit activity to be done.'

Dr. B:'What's your take on the role of higher-order cortex? In the mammalian cortex, we have eight layers, which can be thought of as cortex. What makes me think of cortical neurons that way? The top two layers are dedicated to input and output. The middle layer is dedicated to a range of processes for a wide range that has a place in every part of the cortex. There is a lower layer of cortex and the bottom layer is the higher-order cortex.'
Dr. M:'Yeah.'

Dr. B:-that is the layer where the neurons that have a real place, either on the body, or in the nervous system. Where do you think the neurons that are called cortical neurons go to, and are called, are there neurons? What happens to them? What are they for?'
Dr. M:'That depends on what region of the nervous system you're talking about.'

Dr. M: yeah, maybe they're used during all periods of the lifespan—for the maintenance of the motor patterns or other stuff. There are certainly neuron types that use to serve the needs of different areas of the nervous system and then get repurposed, because there are very different neurons that are used for different functions, including different levels.'

Dr. B:'So what do you mean by circuit? As in neurons connected by their axons and the same synapses, but the circuits that we're thinking about to be able to control are the cortical circuits that are connected with each other by various neurotransmitters. Are they not interconnected and just have some dedicated connectivity, which you'd be interested in developing ways to control?'

Dr. M:'Yes, I mean, sure some connectivity. I mean, like a group of cells that would do a particular thing, you know, and if you can develop a mechanism to do that with a group of cells, this is interesting and it would be really interesting to watch this type of thing work.'

Dr. B:'To have this circuit controlled, and in principle, the entire brain can be controlled, as it was with some people thought. And, and then the question is in principle, what could be done with this circuit? What sort of potential cognitive functions could these neurons be used for that have, and what sort of mechanisms should exist to control these neurons? For instance, I've seen on this blog, where someone talked about using a similar mechanism to regulate certain types of memory. It's a very interesting question. I mean, how would you do that?'

Dr. M:'It's really, you know, we're just going to end up having some sort of set of neurons that are in constant, you know, that have a constant set of voltage thresholds, that can be regulated somehow by the synaptic input that they've, that they receive, because these really neurons, and neurons that are just constantly, like neurons that never stop firing, you know, if you have a set of neurons that just constantly fire, or if you had neurons that have a constant number of spikes per burst, you know, those neurons fire a lot continuously, and then neurons that might be tonically firing.'

Dr. B:'Could you say what that function would be? What do you see in the hippocampus that should be controlled? I'm not talking about that area in particular, but where these neurons are wired to each other and could be responsive to some manipulation. Does it matter what neuronal group the circuit targets, the hippocampus proper, or the septal part that would be targeted, or for example, what do you see for the neocortex or other areas in general?'

Dr. B:'That's what I'm asking at all, at all. So that the activity will move in the direction that we want to move it, and that we want to generate something that is useful for our brain.  Right. And so as soon as you see mechanism, you get a solution to problem X, then it becomes the right direction to research, in which you go toward solving the problems, of X, to do those three things, to control the activity of the network, send messages to the neocortex, and then do something in the brain that's beneficial for it, a useful activity or modification for it, but in a way that, that's where we are. And that's where are the mechanisms that are currently used for control of neural circuits. And we want to move that forward, or enhance it to allow control of the activity of the neural circuits at will.  Okay. And then I'll move to ask you a few questions from the audience.  Okay.'

Dr. M:'I think it has to be with sensory integration so that you can have all kinds of sensory inputs that you want to use to determine, say, movement in the environment. It's not for information processing, as it is in the cortex'.'
Dr. B:'I understand.'
Dr. M: 'Yes'.'

Dr. B:'Do you see it differently? You're a realist, right? You think that once we have the answer, we can work our way up? What is, what is the primary role of the association areas? What is its function?'

Dr. B:'When I was in school, I had to learn about many languages. I was interested mostly in English and Mathematics. In high school, most of my time was spent with friends. At the end of my high school career, I was good friends with a couple of girls, and this was how I entered a path to science. They were the first women I ever met who were able to talk about things like mathematics, physics, chemistry, and anatomy freely, and in high school, I wondered what they did when they grew up. I decided to become a scientist at the University of Lbeck in Lbeck, Germany.'

Dr. B:'Right. Well, then it may be that, for instance, the auditory cortex is there primarily as a sensor that can determine whether you fall off your ledge under the water, and motor and limbic regions are there to calculate what kind of movement you do in those movements to rescue yourself. I mean, the limbic system has long associations with things like emotional states and decision-making and all those things, but it does not have a function within the limbic areas, as I would call it, but that's because the whole point of the limbic system is whether or not an effect should be initiated.'

Dr. M:'Right. Well I think the fact that you have that network that's independent of these things, I don't necessarily think there'll be one primary function or, you know, the whole point is, in fact, the limbic network has all kinds of functions. The auditory sensory network has all kinds. The sensory integration network, the auditory network has all kinds, because you know, the retina and the pylorus, all these muscles have their own individual functions that are not necessarily for moving the body, because those muscles are used by the muscles, and all the muscles that move in the body. So, you know, I think the, if you wanna have a network of many different regions of different neurons that are network in themselves and can generate activity on their own and be integrated with the other regions of the network, I mean, it's possible that that network can generate its own actions. That can happen with the sensory regions.'

Dr. B:'Is it not for information processing? Should we forget that? Are you suggesting... Do you think the association area is not working in the standard way that it is thought about in the mind? It's doing a job of integrating information... It's doing a big job of grouping neural information into useful chunks so that it can be effectively used in any brain region that it would use... So it's doing a big service. The brain is able to integrate in a very reliable way and it's working pretty well. I don't want to ignore how it's working, but I need to make sure to, uh, highlight how our brain is working. I'm saying all this, uh, in the context of, uh, of how the brain works in the cortex. I don't know if you know this, but you know, that was an interesting paper that came out recently called the brain from inside out, which takes stock of all past progress and all future challenges.'

Dr. M:'Yeah, no, uh, which takes stock to the past, so we looked back at earlier studies, so the idea of segmentation was first thought about 70 years ago when some, oh, uh, scientists at Harvard thought, uh, that, uh, brain regions were not uniform neurons, but, uh, that's certainly true. The neurons are distinct. They are distinct because they have their own electrical properties, they're distinct in many biochemical properties but, uh, they also send electrical, uh, electrical information to each other. So we're back, so to the past, but it was clear early on that neurons could contribute substantially to many different neuronal circuits so that's what the association area is for, for, uh, to help you with electrical transmission. Okay?'

Dr. B:'So what's your answer and why would you make a different choice? What is your answer? Why is the association area not working in the way that it is currently thought about? Because that's a big, uh, question, and I want to know if you have a particular answer. And there are, uh, two ways to look at it. One is a, so there's, uh, the first, uh, way of looking at the question is that, uh, if you are looking at the history of brain rhythms, then one can only feel sorry for the lack of a good answer. The rhythm has no meaning to you without a functional interpretation. So this, for instance, uh, theta oscillation in the hippocampus, this is a nice rhythm and I want to make a good use of it. So that's one interpretation.'
Dr. B:'How would you go about understanding that? I mean, how would you approach it?'

Dr. M: 'So, the primary function is integration. You have all kinds of sensors and your choice to use them is a particular kind that would produce a particular sequence of actions, which is your response to some kind of a sensory input. In case of some error, to be aware of the fact that something is erroneous and correct it. As they say the primary function of cortex is to integrate.'
Dr. B:'And then what would such integration include? I mean, what would a mouse integrate? How could you conceptualize something that would match that idea?'
Dr. B:'Would you call, say, the primary function to be integrate and process or would you call it more of an integrating and processing role?'

Dr. M:'No, I would think that is processing. There would have to be integration first and processing. The primary function is to integrate and then you process, but you have to integrate first in order to do anything different.'

Dr. B:'So, I think what's in the main stream, the primary stream of association areas in the cortex is a motor program. Or maybe the best way to say it is that the streams of information are about action rather than processing. You want to make movement. You try to find the connections that can move you. There are, in fact, very few connections that can have high-level effect but they are hard on the backbone; they are low frequency connections. Of course, there's another class of connections, as there are only a few that can also change your mind, as there are few connections that can induce a change in your mind but it is weak. We have a thousand things that are low frequency in the brain, but they have high influence. What we call it 'executive function' which is the ability to use all these signals to move or manipulate the brain according to the immediate needs.'

Dr. B:'Ok, so they are sensory, but they're not sensory, but rather, they provide computational support for incoming signals based on prior knowledge and action trajectories. I could put a camera in. And then you have inputs, and the camera, the brain or you can call it an output system. And then you can put a camera in too to monitor, and use the camera as a proxy for the cortex. This is a different way of trying to figure out how the cortex functions through the eyes of action.'

Dr. M: 'This is an entirely different way of thinking about how the cortex function though the eyes of action. In fact, you can go further, and say the primary goal of the brain is not to sense the world, but to act in it. And this means the primary purpose is to do something else'.'
Dr. B:'What do you think about the motor cortex? It has a lot of neurons devoted to movement.'
Dr. M: 'It is still an action system. There are two layers and a bunch of cells. That is, the cortex is still a system that is very active, but it's mainly in an action-based manner..'
Dr. B:'I see this differently. But if we were to define the association areas, what would it be?'

Dr. M:I agree with you from a functional perspective, but that really is a difficult question to answer objectively. But from a circuit perspective, it would be the neurons with axon collaterals around those neurons with axon collateral that connect those neurons to the sensory, auditory, or other areas of the cortex. So there's really a specific definition, and the key thing would be that axon collaterality in the same brain structure as that neurons, which would have axon collaterally that connect those neurons in that brain structure. What do you think is a functional role?'

Dr. M:'Well I think they're very much required for the association areas, for the coordination between the motor neurons. Because without them, if you don't have one with one motor neuron, if you have some of the other ones, it makes it impossible to coordinate with one, or sometimes if it is a larger group it makes coordinating with them very difficult.'
Dr. B:'Is there anything you're interested in?'
Dr. M:'Really!'
Dr. M: Well, I don't just think about what I talk about.'

Dr. B:'I'm sure there are a lot of things that come to your thinking when you are looking at information. Can you tell us something that you are thinking about right now, and might be able to help us understand? Do you have a piece of research or research program at the moment that you are looking at? Something that you're working on, and it's probably not the most ambitious, but it seems interesting to me, maybe even critical to understand something, and your goal is to understand something. If you can point to something that you're really working on, maybe even a small research program, what are your first steps in that, to start understanding something? It would be amazing if there could be some understanding in the next 12 months that we can have in the next six months that would tell us where we are going here.'
Dr. B:'Why?'
Dr. M:'No I'm not, I study neural signaling. So, I'm interested primarily in neural signaling, I think.'

Dr. B:"The only neurons that have a small number of connections are the Lateral Pyloric and Dorsal Longitudinal Pyloric neurons, because they have a small number connections. So for me, what the primary purpose of these, is to coordinate the actions of a large group of neurons that fire in relatively small groups of neurons. It's not particularly to build a little microcircuit for each individual user, because you have a long interneuron firing. That is the function that I think is the primary function of the connectivity.'
Dr. M: 'How many connections in those neurons?'
Dr. B:'It's hard to give a number, but from various reviews it seems that they're at least hundreds and thousands, and that's a large group of connections that can make up a circuit.'

Dr, M: 'Yes, one of the most striking circuit connections in the brain is in the hippocampus. Where Lateral Pylrical neurons get their inputs from local cortical neurons, and this network can be conceived of as a three-layer, superficial, middle layer, and a third layer and layer connecting layer called the dentate gyrus. These multiple connections require a lot of synapses, in which there are in the hippocampus a couple of trillion synapses, which gives you a tremendous variety of combinations to allow for the large dynamic potential of that network.'
Dr. B:'Why is that? Is there a scientific reason?'
Dr. M:'I think it serves as sort of a boundary. To separate, or to separate the group from each other.'
Dr. B:'Is that a necessary requirement? That is it is there to separate the group, that is it is there, in isolation.'

Dr. M: 'Well, how else could it be achieved? One way is by having a group with a single shared goal, but that works best when some sort of a communication is also made among them, and the communication is only really made when information comes in both directions, or when information is sent between them.'

Dr. M:'It serves as an interface.' In many cases between groups, and some cells do separate from each other. They're not exactly in groups, but still if they're not in groups, if they don't have one of each of their own neurons, they depend on this, these coordination that takes place around them.' 'But the definition of a group?' In many cases as well, there is an association around the periphery between groups, or sometimes there is no apparent association between groups. So it serves as an interface around groups of neurons, and the definition of a network is usually different, usually from the other networks because if they're all very close to the center, then by definition, you don't need the periphery or you can't do that because that's a group. So I mean, they serve a bunch of other functions that aren't particularly related to these other functions.'
Dr. B:'So they're like a wall.'

Dr. M:'They sort of, they have to separate the two groups because sometimes, you know, if things happen and different neurons have to fire together for, for good reason and you know, they want to stop, you know, there could be multiple of them, and they always have to be well separated, yeah, and it's easier, just, you know, in all sorts of other ways it's easier to use the space or to, you know to separate it.'
Dr. B:'Can you give some examples or provide some examples in which that could happen, that is to coordinate with the other ones, in a larger group that doesn't include a specific motor neuron?'

Dr. M:'Well, the primary purpose of a functional anatomy study is to provide insight into an animal's behavior and physiology. And in the nervous system, neurons and other tissue elements are tightly integrated into many different behaviors and therefore you want to study the whole brain.'
Dr. B:'So what is a fundamental difference between your approach and mine?'
Dr. M: 'You know it's like, we both have different visions and different toolsets but I think we just approach the problems in different ways.'

Dr. M:'I study the brain's structure, its circuits, at the level of circuit behavior in the brain. Your approach is really about how the brain works, how a network behaves when you perturb a network. So, if you use a hammer or a scalpel, a knife or a scalpel to cut a brain section out, there are all kinds of circuits that will come out. It will be one circuit connected to the next circuit and different circuits of neurons that will start coming out so you want to study how circuits behave as you gradually remove neurons that are doing different kinds of computations. You understand, and this I think is the fundamental problem with your approach is that if there are 50 different structures there to study, this becomes a very difficult problem to study how they all contribute to behavior.'
Dr. M: So, I am an anatomist, it's the first thing you look at. It is a way of knowing how a brain is organized into functional circuits.'
Dr. B:'And what are the behaviors and physiological patterns that the association areas are involved in?'

Dr. M: Well, these are the kinds of things that happen to other cells. One example is the timing, synchrony of neurons is critical for a variety of brain functions. The other example is the temporal relationship between activity of neurons, and there are dozens, if not hundreds of these types of behaviors in the hippocampus as well as in a variety of cortical areas. And as all of these are brain states associated with oscillations, as I stated earlier they represent a big target of research. We really are in a good position to examine different behaviors and examine how are they supported by brain mechanisms.'

Dr. M:'Well, I think it depends on the preparation. Some mice have one or two small areas -you know, I think the largest one is, like, a little island and then it's smaller than that island in both direction. So that's it. But if you use, you know, if you create these mice with the single-cell-type neuron, then you are essentially generating these network models with a one kind of neuron. And it's really hard to do that, you know because then you have all the complexities of the networks that you want from them, and you also have your single-cell-neuron properties. So in some cases it's simpler to have one or two, you know, maybe three neuron types. So that's the case that I know is, like, simpler in that sense.'
Dr. B:'So, you know, what are the advantages of that? And what are the disadvantages of that?'

Dr. M:'What do you consider as an advantage? I mean I think like how can we do this using smaller numbers of cells, like, you know, as you said initially you had two neurons and the other four were peripheral cells, so how can we build neurons from cells that are different? Like how are we going to do this by starting with five cells and then growing it?'
Dr. B:] 'You know, that's the problem. Can you start with five neurons and grow it? How are we going to grow an army of neurons?'
Dr. M: 'But we still have this problem of how does the network grow?'

Dr. B:'Well, and what is growth? You know, what is the growth? So you may say that it's growth in terms of network size. You may say that it is expansion in the number of cells that a single mouse can have and so forth. There are many other ways, just like you said the number of branches and so the number of things goes on forever. What I'm asking you is what's the strategy? What is your strategy for how this network is going to grow and expand?'
Dr. B:'Is there a goal? Do we know what we want in the future? Or is it just a goal in addition to the science that we are working on?'

Dr. M:'I think that is one of the big issues. It's clear in my mind that when you want to do a cell type experiment, you want to understand something, you know. I have three cell types in my mind for example. So, it's clear. And I think in general, yeah, I think we want to understand how synaptic strengths change or some other properties that may occur in a cell and at how a cell is put together. I think that is one example of when I thought it was clear that I had wanted to understand the mechanisms of synapse reversal potentials and the fact that you can change or change a synaptic connection of a synapse or a synaptic conductance in a neuron to a different direction. Yeah, so that's one thing that really, it wasn't clear. That is, at that point in time, did you know, this wasn't done. So that was the next direction.'

Dr. B:'So, how is it then clear how you would actually find what you would be looking for after several years? Because the longer this goes on, the larger is the problem of the next big thing that we have to do in the brain. It doesn't seem to have an end.'
Dr. B:'Is there a higher order cortex in humans, although there still remains a large degree of controversy.'

Dr. M:'Well, I think—and this is, this is just my personal perspective, as a neuroscientist—I think that is the place where you learn all about your circuit function. So many times in biology it's the case where we know you have this part of the cell, and we know that it is important for the function, but we don't necessarily know exactly how it is used by the cell. A large example is with synaptic inhibitory activity in animals and humans. The synaptic activity of inhibitory synapses is important for muscle contraction or muscle contraction, but not for muscle relaxation. It can also provide the inhibition to the gastric mill rhythm, which is essential for digestion. Right? So the nervous system uses a variety of electrical synapses to maintain function. It uses it to keep the rhythms alive, it uses it to modulate or change the properties of neurons, and that's why it really is so important.'

Dr. B:'A good example of how important this is is the alpha rhythm. This has been recently studied in depth in an incredible way, that it's essential for normal cognition in humans as well as in other animals. It is the largest oscillation in the mammalian brain, and it involves a consortium of many, many, many neurons. You have to work together, and you have to work in time, which is perhaps a fundamental thing that we still haven't solved. Of course, there would be a lot of reasons to solve if the neural syntax would be known. And the way that it would be solved is if we would have a good idea of what information the neurons are communicating in their spikes and how they are being transmitted. Right? That would allow us to do computer-assisted searches and find out in which direction the neurons are firing, and this would let the brain work out what is required. This is the problem that we have to solve.'

Dr. M:'Right. So I have always thought that all neurons are sending information. They're not just firing, you know, they're firing information out to other cells. So, you know, maybe you can fire a tonne of information, but all of the neurons need to be sending information, and the information has to be processed in a way that it can be utilized. There are, obviously, a couple of important neurons that don't want to fire and are silent, but are important, and there are some that just fire continuously, and they are less important, but there may be some other combination. But—of course, there is always the important problem, and that is the problem of how does this—you know, how does this integration of many neurons really happen, and how does it occur, and it's probably not the same in every brain, and it's also probably the consequence of evolution. How does evolution produce the circuit diversity we see across brain circuits throughout evolution?'

Dr. B:'Well, and the problem that we, that we also have to solve is how is this, how is this integration occurring? And, um, it could be a coincidence of timing or, or it could be synchrony, which is the mechanism for neuronal synchronization. The way that is it is happening in the hippocampus, which is a complex, complex system, but it's a synchronized population of neurons. And when you are looking at many neuronal assemblies in this small population, they are sending a different set of messages that the other neurons are receiving. And there are these very critical mechanisms that allow those messages to be processed. It's probably similar in the cerebral cortex. And the messages are also being processed. All these issues must be dealt with when we are thinking about how to understand the function of the brain as it is now. And in addition, we have to find a way to understand what it is because the brain is a complex system.'

Dr. M:'Well, as far as I understand it they're essential for the mouse to be able to hear its mates and smell others of its kind. And also to hear high-frequency sounds. So to me it seemed like a really big deal that for  C. borealis  to behave properly it had to be able to smell others of its own kind. So far, it seems to me that in general, although, as far as mice, cats and monkeys are concerned, they can behave properly as far as social interactions but their nervous systems still haven't gotten to the point where they can behave properly by responding to their own rhythms.'

Dr. B:'The same applies to other parts of the brain such as the visual cortex, which is the main primary sensory organ. So it looks like the primary purpose of this part of the mouse cerebral cortex is to process and transmit the external world to its owner's brain. But what do you think is so special about these parts?'

Dr. B:'What do you think, though, in the case of mice, how the brain can build an independent system from the existing brain networks? Do you think it starts from the very beginning and then makes a long run? How do you think we build in the brain a capacity to use its existing connectivity in order to do more complicated stuff?' (Dr. M does acknowledge in the video description of the TED conversation that, even in the case of the hippocampus-entorhinal loop, where there are hundreds and thousands of oscillations in the mouse, very often these oscillations were discovered subsequently with research that didn't start out with a hypothesis about the function of these oscillations. But she emphasizes it's not that there aren't enough oscillations. What I'm asking is how they can make use of and exploit not only these oscillations but these connections. How do you do new things with the existing?'
Dr. M:'They provide a bridge between sensory and motor circuits.'
Dr. B:'Exactly?'

Dr. M:'So, you take, for example, this, this, this network, which is the primary sensory neuron, the pacemaker of the brain, the core of all the sensory neurons in a small network. When a stimulus comes in through a single sensory or motor neuron, it has nowhere to go, because it has sensory circuits and motor circuits. If you take this network itself, if a stimulus comes through a neuropil, a small aperture that's in the head between the fore- and the central-fornixes, through the pyloric dilator nerve that goes through the lateral ventrical, you can open it up and you can look into the posterior ventrial nerve, which opens up to the association areas where the small motor networks and the small sensory networks are actually in direct contact with each other. The association area is filled with nerves that branch into tiny processes and make direct contact with neurons in the individual networks.'
Dr. B:'So what is the function of these processes?'

Dr. M:'My thesis is the primary purpose is to act as a filter, a receptor. That is to receive small, synaptic inputs that are then amplified to action potentials that can have a tonic action potentials. However, the main function is to filter and then amplify incoming synaptic inputs. To respond to many, many small inputs, small synaptic inputs. We have several synapses that go through the filtering apparatus. For example, the glutamatergic synapse on the pyloric pacemaker (PG) neurons, and the synapse of the anterior pyloric neuron from LP to the PG and to PY. This synapse is small, is only approximately a micrometer and is the first one to be transmitted up the dendrites of the LP neuron and, then, to be relayed to the anterior ganglia. Therefore, it is part of the filtering mechanism.'

Dr. B:'Is the input and output separation so that the glutamater-gic inputs that come in at other neurons, such as the cholinergic and GABAergic inputs, that come in through the associational areas are separated in the upstream parts and then amplified at the downstream parts?'

Dr. M:'The upstream part is amplifying synaptic inputs, which then get further processed at the downstream part. Therefore, the input and output is separated and thus you get, for instance, the segregation of inputs coming from different neurotransmitters.'

Dr. M: 'And then if one of the synapses is inhibited, the other synapses will automatically get activated, because the inhibitory synaptic current is removed from the cell and then the cell will get a depolarized membrane potential and, because of all of these synapses going up to and filtering, amplifying, the depolarized membrane voltage it will be released. So, this is part of the synaptic transmission mechanism. So, the input and the output of a biological synapse are segregated; the input is further processed at the peripheral and the output is processed at the central level.'
